comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: I remember reading somewhere that the British Army adopted the moustache when stationed in India, as it was seen as a sign of authority by local rulers. Can't find that now, but did find on Wikipedia that a moustache was compulsory in the Army from the late 19th century until 1916. From the late 19th century until 1916, British soldiers were forbidden to shave their upper lips. This regulation was finally abolished by an Army Order dated 6 October 1916 issued by Lieutenant-General Sir Nevil Macready, Adjutant-General to the Forces, who loathed his own moustache and immediately shaved it off. The Daily Mail has a piece comparing the rise and fall of Empire with the popularity of the moustache.

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content:
The proper rank term is NCO, i.e. non commissioned officer.

Big moustaches and beards tended to be reduced in size or shaven off during WW1, as a consequence of the use of poison gas,  because they hindered the use of respirators (gas masks).
I've worn one in the army and the rubber has to form a proper seal with the wearer's face.
What's more a big waxed moustache was a good indicator of rank, and with snipers around, being identified as someone with positions of responsibility was not a good or healthy idea!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Lance-Corporals, Corporals, Sergeants and Warrant Officers were collectively Non Commissioned Officers in the British Army. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-commissioned_officer In this photo all have sergeants stripes except for the one seated in the centre. He has a crown on the right sleeve which could indicate a Warrant Officer. The man 3rd from left, back row, has an inverted "horse shoe" above his stripes. Any offers?

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content:
Crown + Cannon + 3 Chevrons = BQMS (Battery Quartermaster Sergeant)
Crown on Lower Sleeve = Regimental Quartermaster Sergeant (later to become WO II)

comment.author: 66941036@N05
comment._content: They are all RFA and the date around 1903,as Boer War medals have been issued.  In 1904 the white belts were replaced by a coloured (multi striped) girdle (a canvas web belt secured by 3 brass olivets) and in 1905 the pill box cap was replaced by a peaked forage cap that is still familiar today.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66941036@N05] Thanks for the info. Apologies for slow response - sometimes it's hard to keep up with all the comments that flood in! The only thing is, we'd be 99% sure this photo was taken on 27 February 1904...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 66941036@N05
comment._content:
1904 would fit, as it took time for the new girdle (coloured belt) to be issued and they do not yet have the new peaked forage cap.  There is absolutely no doubt though, that they are RFA in the 9 button, dark blue full dress tunic, with scarlet collar and yellow worsted braid trim (known as round cord) around the collar and cuffs, with the latter in the form of an Austrian knot.  As a mounted unit (along with RHA), the RFA wore the 'overalls' that you see here, which had a leather strap under the instep of their half wellington boots, with the latter fitted with swan neck spurs.  This full dress uniform was withdrawn upon the outbreak of war in 1914.

I agree with the previous poster that this is very likely to be 145th Field Battery's sergeants and the 'Brigade Sergeant Major' (a warrant officer), pictured outside the Sergeants' Mess.  At that time a group of batteries was known as a Brigade, rather than a Regiment as today.

The man stood at rear with a horseshoe above his chevrons is the "Farrier (Sergeant) Major", as he has a large crown surmounting the badge that indicates his sergeant major status.

Of the seated figures, the man at centre is the Brigade Sergeant Major and his status is reinforced by the gold (gilt) braid trimming his collar and cuffs, instead of the yellow worsted worn by the others.  On his flanks sit two other Sergeant Majors, one for the Battery and the other for the Orderly Room.  There badge of rank was the same and, until 1915, they were not of warrant officer grade.  As SNCOs all the men have gold RA pattern braid around their pillbox caps instead of the plain yellow wool worn by men below the rank of sergeant.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
